articles.headline: Concerned Fed Trims Key Rate by a Half Point
articles.snippet: Even as the Fed reduced its benchmark interest rate to 1 percent, the White House was weighing a plan to slow the foreclosure epidemic in the housing market.
articles.abstract: Even as the Fed reduced its benchmark interest rate to 1 percent, the White House was weighing a plan to slow the foreclosure epidemic in the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve lowered its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point on Wednesday, its second big rate cut this month, as policy makers tried to fend off what could be the worst economic downturn in decades.

articles.headline: Colombia Lists Civilian Killings in Guerrilla Toll
articles.snippet: Civilians are increasingly becoming victims of Colombia’s long internal war against leftist insurgencies.
articles.abstract: Civilians are increasingly becoming victims of Colombia’s long internal war against leftist insurgencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOACHA, Colombia  Julián Oviedo, a 19-year-old construction worker in this gritty patchwork of slums, told his mother on March 2 that he was going to talk to a man about a job offer. A day later, Mr. Oviedo was shot dead by army troops some 350 miles to the north. He was classified as a subversive and registered as a combat kill.

articles.headline: BlackBerry Aims to Stay Step Ahead
articles.snippet: The BlackBerry Flip and the BlackBerry Bold have arrived, each with a feature that shouts, “Take that, iPhone.”
articles.abstract: The BlackBerry Flip and the BlackBerry Bold have arrived, each with a feature that shouts, “Take that, iPhone.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Boy, oh boy. The bunch who brought you the BlackBerry sure has been a band of busy beavers.

articles.headline: As Gas Prices Go Down, Driving Goes Up
articles.snippet: The decline in gasoline use earlier this year suggested the possibility of a permanent change in driving habits. But with prices down, drivers are returning to their old ways.
articles.abstract: The decline in gasoline use earlier this year suggested the possibility of a permanent change in driving habits. But with prices down, drivers are returning to their old ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: VINTON, La.  Doug Guidry gave up drag racing and boating last summer when gasoline prices shot up. Billy Castaneda put off trips to Houston to see his grandchildren. Randal Shul stopped playing paintball with his buddies to save gas.

articles.headline: The Decided Go in Droves to Vote Early
articles.snippet: Early voting has been a hit, in grocery stores or out car windows, and millions have already cast ballots.
articles.abstract: Early voting has been a hit, in grocery stores or out car windows, and millions have already cast ballots.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev.  At grocery stores across Las Vegas, voters are casting their ballots, and then shopping for bananas or hitting the slot machines a few feet away.

articles.headline: At Rallies of Faithful, Contrasts in Red and Blue
articles.snippet: It is a cliché to say that the country is “divided,” but 11 recent campaign stops offer glimpses of partisan America.
articles.abstract: It is a cliché to say that the country is “divided,” but 11 recent campaign stops offer glimpses of partisan America.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIPPENSBURG, Pa.  Supporters of Senators Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden Jr. often look like Benetton-colored billboards, decked out for their candidates in Obama-Biden hats, T-shirts and buttons. Supporters of Senator John McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin like logo merchandise, too, but tend more toward pompoms (yes, pompoms), homemade signs (“Pitbulls 4 Freedom”), flag pins and chest paint.

articles.headline: A Question for A.I.G.: Where Did the Cash Go?
articles.snippet: A.I.G. is rapidly running through $123 billion in emergency lending provided by the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: A.I.G. is rapidly running through $123 billion in emergency lending provided by the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group is rapidly running through $123 billion in emergency lending provided by the Federal Reserve, raising questions about how a company claiming to be solvent in September could have developed such a big hole by October. Some analysts say at least part of the shortfall must have been there all along, hidden by irregular accounting.

articles.headline: Cuomo Asks for Pay Data From Banks
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general expanded his investigation of bonuses to Wall Street executives whose banking companies are receiving cash injections from the federal government.
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general expanded his investigation of bonuses to Wall Street executives whose banking companies are receiving cash injections from the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street is coming under mounting political pressure to cut bonuses for top executives, traders and bankers in what was already expected to be a down year for pay.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Seeing Gold in Target’s Real Estate
articles.snippet: An activist investor, hoping for a big increase in market value, has proposed that Target sell the land underneath its stores to a new unit set up for the purpose.
articles.abstract: An activist investor, hoping for a big increase in market value, has proposed that Target sell the land underneath its stores to a new unit set up for the purpose.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial engineering may have fallen into ill repute in Washington and much of the country, but let no one imagine that Wall Street has given up.

articles.headline: Economy Shrinks With Consumers Leading the Way
articles.snippet: The economy contracted from July through September, the government reported, while consumer spending dipped for the first time in 17 years.
articles.abstract: The economy contracted from July through September, the government reported, while consumer spending dipped for the first time in 17 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a week before Americans go to the polls to select a president, the government reported on Thursday that the economy contracted from July through September. In a stark indication of widening national distress, consumer spending dipped for the first time in 17 years.
